Morning Light in the Royal Bedchamber
Toledo, Late January 1431
One Week After the Wedding

The winter morning light filters through the heavy curtains, casting the bedchamber in soft grays and golds. Isabel lies in Juan's arms afterward, still catching her breath, her dark hair loose across the pillows. She's grown accustomed to these moments over the past week—the initial strangeness has faded, replaced by a quiet comfort in his presence, in his touch.

When Juan says he loves her, she feels a small flutter in her chest—pleasure, warmth, a sense of being valued. She's not overwhelmed by passion, but there's genuine fondness growing in her heart, like a plant taking root in good soil.

She turns her head slightly to look at him, her plain features soft in the morning light. A small, shy smile touches her lips. Her hand finds his where it rests on her waist, her fingers curling around his gently.

"I... I am content, my lord," she says quietly, her voice carrying that careful modesty she was raised with. "More than content. You have been so kind to me. So gentle."

She pauses, gathering her thoughts. Speaking about such intimate matters makes her blush, but Juan's question deserves an honest answer.

"I prayed for months about this marriage," she continues, her thumb tracing small circles on the back of his hand. "I was frightened, leaving Portugal. Frightened of... all of this." A delicate gesture that encompasses the bed, their intimacy, her new life. "But God has been merciful. You have been merciful."

Her eyes meet his—earnest, warm, if not quite burning with passion. "I like being your wife, Juan. I like waking beside you. I like our evening prayers together. I like..." she colors slightly, but presses on with characteristic dutiful honesty, "...I like when you hold me, as you are now."

She shifts closer, resting her head against his shoulder with a small sigh of contentment. "I think we shall do well together. Better than well." A pause. "I am... I am happy. Truly."

It's clear she means it. This is not fiery, all-consuming love—not yet, perhaps not ever—but it's real affection, growing trust, genuine fondness. For a girl raised on duty and devotion, this warmth and safety is more than she dared hope for from an arranged marriage.

Royal Bedchamber, Toledo
Early February 1431
Morning

Juan kisses Isabel gently on the forehead before rising from the bed. The stone floor is cold against his feet, but servants have already been in to stoke the fire—the room is warming nicely. He moves to the basin where fresh water awaits, steam rising faintly in the winter air.

As he washes and dresses, servants attend him with practiced efficiency. His attire today is practical—a fine doublet in deep blue with the Castilian arms embroidered on the chest, sturdy boots, a heavy cloak lined with fur against the February chill. This is the king inspecting his warriors, not holding court.

Isabel watches from the bed, pulling the covers modestly around herself, her dark hair still loose. There's something peaceful about her expression—content, as she said. Not passion, perhaps, but genuine warmth.

"I'll return for our evening prayers," Juan tells her as he buckles his sword belt. "Rest if you wish. Or Doña Beatriz mentioned the Portuguese chapel renovations are nearly complete—you might want to see them."

The Crusader Encampment
Outside Toledo's Eastern Walls

The ride through Toledo's streets takes Juan past the cathedral, where construction continues even in winter, past the Jewish quarter with its synagogues and workshops, and finally through the eastern gate where the crusader encampment spreads across the hills.

What had been 151 men in November has swelled dramatically. The recruitment proclamation distributed after your wedding, read in churches and market squares across Castile, has brought a flood of applicants. The careful screening by Fray Hernando and the crusader captains means not all are accepted—but many are.

Current count: 267 sworn crusaders.

The encampment is well-organized. White tents arranged in neat rows, each with eight men. A central area for training. A chapel tent where Mass is said daily. Supply wagons, smithies, armories. This is no longer a symbolic gathering—this is the core of an army.

As Juan approaches on horseback with his guard, a horn sounds. Men emerge from tents, form up in rough formations. They're not professional soldiers trained to parade ground perfection, but they're learning discipline.

Captain García Fernández—one of the original four crusaders, now promoted to training commander—strides forward and drops to one knee. He's a grizzled veteran, scars on his face, eyes that have seen battle.

"Your Majesty," he says, his voice carrying. "Two hundred sixty-seven sworn crusaders await your inspection. Fifty-three new arrivals this week alone."

Behind him, the men stand at attention. They're a mix: younger sons of minor nobility in decent armor, prosperous farmers who could afford equipment, a few merchants' sons, even several former soldiers seeking redemption or adventure. All wear white surcoats over their armor or clothing—the crusader's mark.

The morning sun catches on mail, on sword hilts, on the white banner flying above the central tent—a smaller version of the banner bearing the True Cross fragment that remains in the royal chapel.

"Your Majesty!" He bows quickly, his Castilian heavily accented. "You come at good time. We are drilling the third crew today. Watch, watch."

He gestures toward one of the active bombards. A crew of six men works around it with practiced but not yet perfect coordination:

The loading process:

One man swabs the barrel with a wet sponge on a pole—cleaning out residue

Another measures gunpowder from a barrel, pouring it carefully down the barrel

A third rams a wooden sabot and wadding down with a long pole

Two men roll a stone ball (perhaps 50 pounds) to the muzzle and lever it in

More wadding is rammed down

The master gunner checks the aim, adjusts the elevation with wooden wedges

Pietro shouts: "¡Fuego!"

The slowmatch touches the touch-hole. For a heartbeat, nothing—then:

BOOM!

The bombard belches flame and smoke, lurching backward against its restraints. The stone ball arcs through the air and—after what seems like forever—crashes into a earthwork target about 300 yards away, sending dirt flying.

The crew cheers. Pietro nods approval but makes notes on a slate.

"Not bad, not bad," he mutters. He turns to Juan. "Your Majesty, we have five bombards ready. Could have six, but one had casting flaw—dangerous, sent it back to foundry. These five, they are good. Strong bronze, proper design."

He walks Juan along the line, explaining each piece:

Artillery Status:

5 medium bombards operational (originally ordered 4-6)

Each can fire 40-50 pound stone balls approximately 300-400 yards accurately

Rate of fire: 10-12 shots per day per bombard if pressing hard, 6-8 if careful

Gunpowder supply: Adequate for the campaign season, stored carefully in dry magazines

Stone shot: Stonemasons are cutting balls continuously; hundreds already stockpiled

Crew Training:

"We have trained five crews now," Pietro explains. "Each crew six men plus me or one of my two assistants supervising. They are learning. Not perfect yet—still slow, sometimes make mistakes. But by April?" He shrugs. "They will be competent. Not masters, but competent. Can breach wall given time."

He points to the earthwork targets showing crater damage. "In siege, Your Majesty, these bombards will pound same spot on wall for days. Stone cracks, mortar crumbles. Three days, maybe five days of steady fire? Wall comes down. Much faster than trebuchet, much faster than starvation."

The Challenge:

"The hard part, Your Majesty, is not firing. Is moving them. Each bombard weighs nearly one ton. The carriage, another ton. Must have eight oxen to pull each one. Roads must be good, or we get stuck. And protection—" he gestures seriously, "—Granada has archers, cavalry. Guns are slow, vulnerable. Need infantry protection always."

He shows Juan the support train: wagons of gunpowder (kept far apart in case of accident), carts of stone shot, barrels of tools and spare parts, the oxen teams being trained to not panic at the cannon fire.

Assessment:

The artillery program is progressing well. Not perfect, but solid. By April, these five bombards should be ready to deploy with the western army to begin the systematic reduction of coastal fortresses.

Pietro adds one concern: "Your Majesty, Granada has Ottoman guns too. Maybe better than ours. When we besiege their fortresses, they shoot back. My men must learn to work under fire. We will practice, but..." He shrugs. "First real siege, some will panic. Is normal. They will learn or they will die."

What does Juan say or do?

Artillery Status Summary:

Operational Bombards: 5 medium pieces

Trained Crews: 5 crews (6 men each = 30 gunners)

Master Gunners: 3 (Pietro + 2 assistants)

Gunpowder Supply: Adequate for 8-month campaign

Stone Shot: Hundreds prepared, more being cut

Transport: 40 oxen trained and assigned

Readiness: On track for April deployment

Estimated Effectiveness: Can breach fortress walls in 3-5 days of concentrated fire

Great job and continue to train. But you will fight with me on the eastern front. Does not change much in regards to your training, butsomething to keep in mind. I will deploy you against the walls of the fortresess there.


Keep on training. We move out at the beginning of April. Anything you need?

Artillery Grounds, Western Edge of Toledo
Early February 1431

Pietro Calabrese's eyebrows rise slightly at this information. He thinks for a moment, then nods slowly.

"Eastern front, Your Majesty. With the raiding forces and the banner." He scratches his scarred chin. "This changes some things, yes. Eastern front is more... how do you say... opportunistic? We hit targets when we find them, not systematic siege campaign."

He considers the implications. "Means we must be more mobile. Ready to move quickly when intelligence finds weak fortress or opportunity. Western coast campaign—that would be slow, methodical, one fortress after another. Eastern front—we might sit idle for week, then suddenly need to set up siege in two days."

Pietro walks back toward the bombards, Juan following. "Is good, actually. My crews learn to work fast, work under pressure. And eastern fortresses..." he grins, showing missing teeth, "...maybe not as strong as coastal ones. Granada puts their best defenses on coast where Christian navies threaten. Inland fortresses, frontier castles—older, weaker walls perhaps."

His Needs:

"What I need, Your Majesty, for eastern deployment:

First—good scouts and intelligence. My guns are useless if we don't know which fortresses are worth attacking. Need to know: how thick are walls? How many defenders? Can we get guns into position? I need reconnaissance before we commit to siege.

Second—more oxen teams. Eastern terrain is mountains, bad roads. If we get stuck, we hold up entire army. I want eight oxen per gun, maybe need ten in mountains. And spare oxen, because they die—sickness, enemy raids, accidents.

Third—infantry protection always. My crews work slow, exposed. Granada cavalry sees artillery train, they attack. Need good infantry, archers, cavalry screen while we work. This is Commander's responsibility, but I say it now: protect the guns or lose them.

Fourth—covered wagons for powder. Rain ruins gunpowder. Spain has spring rains, yes? I need good canvas covers, maybe wooden carts with roofs. Keep powder dry at all costs.

Fifth—" he hesitates, then continues, "—authority to refuse suicide missions. Your Majesty, sometimes commanders see big gun and think 'we can take any fortress now!' But some fortresses, the terrain is wrong, walls too thick, defenders too many. If I say 'this siege will fail, we waste ammunition and men,' I need your backing to refuse. I serve you, but I will not throw away guns and crews on impossible tasks just because some nobleman wants glory."

He meets Juan's eyes directly. "I am expensive, Your Majesty. My crews are trained, my guns are valuable. Use us well, and we win you fortresses. Use us badly, and you lose everything. I need authority to say 'no' when operation is foolish."

Does Juan grant Pietro this authority and agree to his other needs?

Pietro's Requirements:

Good reconnaissance/intelligence before siege commitments

Extra oxen teams (10 per gun instead of 8, plus spares)

Guaranteed infantry/cavalry protection during operations

Weather-protected gunpowder transport

Authority to advise against tactically unsound siege operations

You shall have the oxen and protection you need master gunner.


Beginning April we start to push into Grenada. Will you be ready by then? How long will your travel to the front take?

For readiness:
- Pietro said the crews are learning, will be "competent" by April
- They have 5 operational bombards
- They're training now
- About 2 months left to train
- Pietro seems confident they'll be ready

For travel time:
- Heavy artillery with oxen teams moves very slowly
- From Toledo to the Granada frontier (eastern approach, likely toward the Jaén area or similar)
- Medieval ox-drawn heavy loads: maybe 10-15 miles per day on good roads, less on bad terrain
- Distance from Toledo to Granada frontier: roughly 200-250 miles depending on route
- So maybe 15-20 days of travel minimum, possibly longer
- Plus they need to coordinate with the army, not travel alone (vulnerable)
- Roads in spring might be muddy from rains
- Terrain gets mountainous as they approach Granada

Pietro would be realistic about this - he's experienced. He'd want to leave with plenty of time to spare.

Artillery Grounds, Western Edge of Toledo
Early February 1431

Pietro nods gratefully at the promise of oxen and protection. "Good, Your Majesty. With those, we can work."

He considers the timeline question carefully, his experienced eyes calculating. "Ready by April? Sí, we will be ready. My crews train every day now. By April first, they know their work—load, aim, fire, maintain. Not perfect, but competent. Good enough for war."

Then he addresses the more complex question—the march itself. He walks to a rough map pinned to a board near the magazine, showing the route from Toledo to the Granada frontier.

"Travel time, Your Majesty... this is the problem." He traces the route with a powder-stained finger. "Toledo to Granada frontier—to Jaén, Úbeda, wherever your eastern army concentrates—is perhaps two hundred fifty miles, maybe more. Through La Mancha, then into mountains."

He taps the map. "My guns with full ammunition train, powder wagons, support carts—we are slow. Very slow. On good flat roads in La Mancha, maybe fifteen miles per day with full ox teams. In the mountains approaching Granada?" He makes a face. "Ten miles per day. Maybe eight if roads are bad, if spring rains make mud."

Pietro does the calculation aloud: "Two hundred fifty miles... if we average twelve miles per day, that is twenty days of travel. But we cannot march every day—oxen must rest, wheels break, we must stop for repairs. And we should not travel alone—too vulnerable. Must move with army or strong escort."

He straightens, meeting Juan's eyes. "Your Majesty, if campaign begins April first, I must leave Toledo by March tenth. Maybe earlier, March fifth to be safe. This gives us three weeks travel time with margin for problems."

"But better—" he continues, "—if I coordinate with your main eastern army assembly. When do your forces concentrate? Where? If I march with army, we have protection, and I arrive exactly when needed. If I march alone or with small escort, we might arrive early and sit exposed, or late and miss first opportunity."

He crosses his arms. "So, Your Majesty—when and where does eastern army assemble for campaign? I will plan my departure to join them, or to arrive at staging area same time they do."

What does Juan tell Pietro about the army assembly timeline and location?

Artillery Movement Calculation:

Distance: ~250 miles Toledo to Granada frontier

Speed: 10-15 miles/day depending on terrain

Travel time: 20-25 days including rest

Departure needed: Early to mid-March (March 5-10)

Recommendation: Coordinate with main army assembly for protection and timing

March towards Jaen. You will be directed further after then.


If there is nothing further, get to it.

Artillery Grounds, Western Edge of Toledo
Early February 1431

Pietro Calabrese nods sharply, committing the orders to memory. "Jaén. Capisco—I understand, Your Majesty. We march toward Jaén in early March, arrive by month's end, await further orders there."

He straightens, placing his fist over his heart in a rough salute. "My guns will be ready, Your Majesty. My crews will be ready. We will serve you well."

As Juan turns to leave, Pietro adds one last thing, his voice carrying genuine respect: "Your Majesty—is good you inspect your forces yourself. Good you see the guns, the crusaders, the preparations. Some kings just give orders and expect miracles. You come, you look, you understand what is real. This is why we will win."

He bows, then immediately turns back to his crews, barking orders in Italian-accented Spanish about powder measurements and barrel alignment.

The Royal Alcázar, Toledo
Late Morning

Juan rides back through Toledo's streets toward the Alcázar. The winter sun is climbing higher now, though the air remains crisp. The inspection tour has consumed most of the morning—crusaders, artillery, all progressing well toward the April campaign launch.

As he enters the Alcázar courtyard and dismounts, a servant hurries forward. "Your Majesty, Don Álvaro requests audience when convenient. He says correspondence has arrived from Seville—from Don Rodrigo Manrique regarding crusader recruitment there."

The letter Juan was planning to write about Seville recruitment—it seems Rodrigo has anticipated the question.

What does Juan do?

Location: Royal Alcázar, Toledo
Pending: Álvaro has correspondence from Rodrigo about Seville crusader recruitment

Rodrigo Manrique reports from Seville: 101 original crusaders in excellent shape, 27 new recruits accepted (of 43 applicants), total 128 in Seville, projecting 150-170 by April. Juan orders formal noble levy summons sent immediately with assembly deadline March 25 at staging areas — no staggered arrivals. Isabel stays with army until pregnancy confirmed, then returns to Toledo.

exchanges.text: I meet with Alvaro

Don Álvaro's Office, Royal Alcázar
Late Morning, Early February 1431

Juan is shown into Álvaro's working chambers, a spacious room lined with documents, maps, and correspondence. The Royal Constable rises from behind his desk, several letters spread before him.

"Your Majesty," Álvaro greets him with a bow. "I trust the inspection went well? The crusaders are progressing?"

He gestures to a chair and pours wine—a light midday refreshment. Once Juan is seated, Álvaro picks up one of the letters, breaking the wax seal that shows Rodrigo Manrique's personal device.

"This arrived by fast courier this morning from Seville. Don Rodrigo reports on the preparations there—including crusader recruitment." Álvaro scans the letter, then reads aloud the relevant sections:

From Don Rodrigo Manrique, Seville
Dated January 30, 1431

"...The one hundred crusaders Your Majesty left in my charge continue their training with dedication. Captain Alonso Pérez has maintained excellent discipline, and there have been no desertions or significant problems.

Regarding recruitment: The proclamation distributed after His Majesty's wedding has reached Seville and the surrounding regions. We have received forty-three applications for crusader service here in Seville. After screening by our chaplains and assessment of military capability, we have accepted twenty-seven new crusaders. They began their oaths and training last week.

The recruitment pace in Seville is notably slower than what I understand Toledo is experiencing. I attribute this to two factors: First, many young men from western Castile have already traveled to Toledo hoping to join His Majesty's personal forces under the banner. Second, Seville's population is more merchant and maritime—fewer men with military experience or inclination.

However, the quality of our Seville recruits is generally high. Several are former sailors with combat experience against Barbary corsairs. Others are sons of the military orders' administrative families. They understand naval operations and coastal warfare, which will serve the western campaign well.

By my estimate, if recruitment continues at this pace, Seville will provide perhaps fifty to seventy additional crusaders by campaign start—giving us a total Seville force of one hundred fifty to one hundred seventy crusaders for the western army..."

Álvaro looks up from the letter. "So, Your Majesty—combining reports: Toledo has two hundred sixty-seven crusaders currently, Seville has one hundred twenty-seven total. That's three hundred ninety-four crusaders sworn, with recruitment continuing in both cities."

He sets the letter down. "Rodrigo also reports on other preparations—artillery coordination, naval contracts with Genoese captains, supply depot establishment. The western army preparations are proceeding smoothly. He expects to be ready to march by early April as planned."

Álvaro pauses, then adds: "There's one other matter Rodrigo mentions. The Infantes—Juan and Enrique—have been cooperative in their crusader service preparations, but Rodrigo notes they seem... subdued. Going through motions correctly but without enthusiasm. He wonders if we should be concerned about their commitment once the campaign actually begins and they're far from oversight."

The Constable pours more wine, his expression thoughtful. "Your Majesty, is there anything specific you wish me to communicate back to Rodrigo? Or any other matters we should address while we're reviewing preparations?"

What does Juan say or ask?

Crusader Status Update:

Toledo: 267 currently

Seville: 127 (100 original + 27 newly recruited)

Total Sworn: 394 crusaders

Projected by April: 500-550 total

Everything seems to be in order. We march south soon to start with cavalry probing the border forts. After a few weeks we will march ahead with our main army and drive into Grenada. 
As soon as the sultan deploys against us, we signal for the naval operation in the west to start.


Send out summons if we have not done so already for the nobles to deploy in the eastern and western armies. Especially the great noble houses are required to came with all their levies. I choose Jaen as a staging area for our eastern army for now.

The strategy Juan outlines:
1. Cavalry probing border forts first (light forces)
2. Main army marches after a few weeks
3. When Sultan deploys against eastern army, signal western naval operation to begin
4. This is smart - draw Granada's attention east, then hit them west when committed

Álvaro would likely:
- Confirm whether summons have been sent
- If not, draft them immediately
- Confirm the staging area (Jaén)
- Possibly raise practical questions about timeline
- Discuss the coordination between eastern and western operations

Let me write this response with Álvaro being the capable administrator he is.

Don Álvaro's Office, Royal Alcázar
Late Morning, Early February 1431

Álvaro listens carefully to Juan's strategic outline, nodding as he absorbs the operational plan. When Juan finishes, the Constable sets down his wine and pulls a fresh sheet of parchment toward him, dipping his quill.

"A sound strategy, Your Majesty—draw Granada's main forces east with our concentrated army and the banner, then unleash the naval assault on their western coast when they're committed against you." He makes notes as he speaks. "They cannot ignore your presence with the True Cross and the crusader host. When they march to meet you, their coastal defenses are weakened."

He looks up. "Regarding the noble summons—we have not yet issued the formal levy call. The recruitment proclamation for crusaders went out after your wedding, but the mandatory noble levy summons has not been sent. We were planning to issue it in late March, giving nobles approximately four weeks to assemble and march. But if Your Majesty wishes them sent now..."

Álvaro calculates quickly. "Early February now. If we send summons this week, nobles have nine to ten weeks to gather their forces and reach the staging areas. More than adequate—perhaps even too generous. Some will dawdle. But it does give the great houses no excuse for delay."

He begins drafting the key points:

"Formal Summons to Issue Immediately:

To Eastern Army (Staging at Jaén):

All nobles holding lands in Leon, Old Castile, New Castile, Extremadura

Required to present with full feudal levies

Staging point: Jaén

Assembly deadline: March 25th (giving 7 weeks)

Commander: His Majesty Juan II, with Master of Calatrava as field marshal

To Western Army (Staging at Seville):

All nobles holding lands in Andalusia, Murcia, western territories

Required to present with full feudal levies

Staging point: Seville

Assembly deadline: March 25th (giving 7 weeks)

Commander: Don Rodrigo Manrique"

Álvaro taps the parchment. "The great houses specifically..." He lists them: "Mendoza, Guzmán, Enríquez, Manrique, Álvarez de Toledo, Pimentel, Velasco—all will be named explicitly with their required contributions. No ambiguity, no excuses."

He pauses, then adds a practical consideration: "Your Majesty, you mentioned cavalry probing operations beginning first, then the main army weeks later. Should the summons specify staggered arrival? Light cavalry first, then heavy forces? Or should everyone assemble at Jaén by late March and we organize operations from there?"

"Also—" Álvaro glances at another document, "—the coordination signal between your eastern operations and Rodrigo's western assault. How shall this be managed? Courier riders? Smoke signals visible from mountain peaks? This must be planned carefully. If the signal is delayed or missed, we lose the strategic advantage."

What does Juan specify about the timing and coordination?

Summons Status:

Formal levy summons not yet issued

Can be sent immediately (early February)

Gives nobles ~7 weeks to assemble (by late March)

Staging areas: Jaén (East), Seville (West)

Coordination Questions:

Staggered arrival or all-at-once assembly?

How to signal between eastern and western armies?

We change nothing about our signal system. It is in place, it is enough. And we do not stagger arrival. Uncertainty enough, they just have to wait a bit in Jaen. Send out summons and tell them we expect them to be present and ready 25 March. And make sure both armies recieve enouth troops. The west must total 12.000, the east 23.000. But we have already made these calculations.


Anything else we should discuss?

Don Álvaro's Office, Royal Alcázar
Late Morning, Early February 1431

Álvaro nods briskly, making final notes on the summons draft. "Understood, Your Majesty. Signal system remains as planned, no staggered arrivals, assembly deadline March 25th at both staging points. The force compositions are already calculated—twelve thousand for the west under Don Rodrigo, twenty-three thousand for the east under your direct command. I'll have the formal summons drafted today and sent by courier tomorrow to every major house."

He sets aside the parchment and reviews his other documents briefly. "A few other matters for Your Majesty's awareness, though none require immediate decisions:

First— the forty-three tax assessors are trained and ready to deploy with the armies in April, as planned. Father Tommaso's administrators will coordinate with them. Cardinal Capranica's ecclesiastical observers will join them as well.

Second— the Portuguese dowry funds—one hundred eighty thousand florins—were transferred to the royal treasury upon your wedding. Combined with existing funds, we have three hundred ninety thousand florins available for campaign expenses and reserves.

Third— the Genoese naval contracts. Rodrigo is finalizing terms but expects all twelve combat galleys and ten transport vessels to be secured by mid-March. The Portuguese galleys from the dowry are already being prepared in Lisbon."

Álvaro pauses, then asks: "Your Majesty, do you intend to remain here in Toledo until the March departure, or will you return to Seville before the campaign? There are advantages to either—Toledo keeps you close to the crusader recruitment and training, but Seville is closer to final preparations for both armies."

He adds with a slight smile: "Also, the Queen might appreciate knowing how long you'll be in residence before marching to war."

What does Juan decide about his immediate plans?

Current Status Summary:

Date: Early February 1431

Treasury: 390,000 florins available

Crusaders: 394 sworn (Toledo + Seville)

Noble Summons: Being sent immediately, assembly March 25

Campaign Start: April 1431

Artillery: 5 bombards ready, crews training

Current Location: Toledo with Isabel

Put the tax assessors to work to both inspect the army spends correctly and to assess the revenues of estates in Castille. We march south soon to Jaen, I will split off and visit Seville quickly. Isabel will stay in Jaen for a few days before I get back. I think we will leave at the beginning of March to keep it comfortable for Isabel.

Don Álvaro's Office, Royal Alcázar
Late Morning, Early February 1431

Álvaro nods, making careful notes. "Excellent, Your Majesty. The assessors will deploy with dual purpose—financial oversight of campaign expenditures and revenue assessment of noble estates. Father Tommaso will coordinate the division of responsibilities."

He pauses at Juan's travel plans, considering the logistics. "Early March departure for Jaén—that gives us about four weeks to finalize preparations here. The journey to Jaén is approximately one hundred twenty miles, perhaps six to seven days of comfortable travel for the Queen. Then Your Majesty makes a quick visit to Seville—another eighty miles, two to three days each way—while the Queen rests in Jaén."

Álvaro sets down his quill and looks at Juan directly. "Your Majesty, may I speak frankly about the Queen's presence at Jaén?"

At Juan's nod, he continues: "Jaén is the staging area for twenty-three thousand troops. By late March it will be a military encampment—soldiers, supplies, noise, limited amenities. The Queen will be safe, certainly, with proper quarters in the fortress and adequate guard. But it is not... comfortable. Not like Toledo or even a peaceful castle."

He chooses his words carefully. "Some kings leave their queens in secure, comfortable locations during campaigns. Toledo, for instance, or Burgos. The Queen could maintain court, manage correspondence, coordinate with Church authorities. She would be far from any danger, in familiar surroundings."

"Alternatively," Álvaro adds, "if Your Majesty wishes the Queen closer to the campaign—for morale, for the symbolic unity of the crusade—Jaén serves that purpose. But it requires accepting certain... inconveniences for Her Majesty."

He spreads his hands. "This is Your Majesty's decision, of course. I merely wish to ensure you've considered the practical realities. The Queen is young, newly arrived in Castile, and has shown herself dutiful but not... accustomed to military camps."

How does Juan respond regarding Isabel's presence at the staging area?

Travel Timeline:

Departure from Toledo: Early March

Arrival in Jaén: Mid-March (6-7 day journey)

Juan's Seville visit: 5-6 days round trip

Campaign start: April

Isabel's situation: Would be in military staging area with 23,000 troops assembling

She is not pregnant yet. She will stay with me until she is. Shen she is, she will leave for Toledo to give birth.


Any other matters that require our attention?

Don Álvaro's Office, Royal Alcázar
Late Morning, Early February 1431

Álvaro nods at Juan's practical approach, making a note. "Understood, Your Majesty. The Queen travels with the army until pregnancy is confirmed, then returns to Toledo for safety and proper care. A sensible arrangement."

He reviews his documents one final time, checking for any other pressing matters. "I believe we've covered the essential preparations, Your Majesty. The summons will go out tomorrow. Crusader recruitment and training continues. Artillery crews drill daily. The assessors and administrators are ready to deploy. Naval contracts are being finalized."

He sets the papers aside. "The next major milestone is early March—departure for Jaén. Until then, it's a matter of allowing the preparations to continue. The machinery is in motion."

Álvaro pauses, then adds with a slight smile: "Your Majesty, you've spent the morning inspecting crusaders and artillery. The afternoon is yours. The Queen mentioned yesterday that the Portuguese chapel renovations are nearly complete—perhaps she would appreciate seeing them with you?"

The Constable stands, bowing. "Unless Your Majesty requires anything else, I'll begin drafting the formal noble summons and coordinate with Father Tommaso on the assessor deployments."

What does Juan do with the rest of his day?

Treasury: 390,000 florins

Crusaders: 394 sworn (267 Toledo, 127 Seville)

Artillery: 5 bombards, trained crews

Noble Summons: Being issued (assembly March 25)

Departure for Jaén: Early March

events.summary: Afternoon with Isabel. They inspect the completed Portuguese chapel — Portuguese heraldry, saints, blue-and-white color scheme, private devotional shrine. Juan prays a deeply personal, vulnerable prayer: asks God's blessing on their marriage, the crusade, Isabel's comfort in a foreign land, and for children. Isabel is profoundly moved and prays her own response, then opens up about struggling to express emotions she was never taught to articulate. exchanges.text:
Get to is Alvaro.


I will visit Isabel now.


I go to her.

The Queen's Chambers, Royal Alcázar
Early Afternoon, Early February 1431

Álvaro bows as Juan departs. "At once, Your Majesty. The summons will be ready by evening for your review before dispatch."

Juan makes his way through the Alcázar's corridors toward Isabel's chambers. The palace is busy with midday activity—servants carrying linens, clerks hurrying with documents, courtiers lingering in conversation. They all bow or curtsy as their king passes.

He reaches Isabel's apartments and the guards announce him. Inside, he finds the chambers warm and well-lit, the fire crackling pleasantly. Doña Beatriz and two other Portuguese ladies are present, working on embroidery near the windows where the winter light is strongest.

Isabel herself sits at a small writing desk, carefully composing a letter. She's dressed in a deep burgundy gown, her dark hair partially covered by a simple veil. When Juan enters, she looks up, and a genuine smile crosses her plain features—the kind of smile that comes naturally now, not the careful dutiful expression she wore in their first weeks.

"My lord!" She sets down her quill and rises, curtsying. The Portuguese ladies immediately stand as well, bowing.

Isabel dismisses them with a gesture. "Please, leave us." Doña Beatriz gathers the other ladies, and they withdraw to the adjoining chamber, closing the door but remaining within call as propriety requires.

When they're alone, Isabel's formality relaxes slightly. She moves toward Juan, her movements easy, comfortable. "I wasn't expecting you until evening prayers. How were the crusaders? And the artillery?"

There's genuine interest in her voice—she's been listening to his talk of preparations, trying to understand this campaign that consumes so much of his attention.

She glances back at her writing desk. "I was writing to my mother in Portugal. Telling her about..." a slight blush, "...about married life. That I'm content. That you're kind to me."

What does Juan say or do?

Time: Early afternoon
Location: Isabel's chambers, private
Isabel's mood: Comfortable, affectionate, genuinely pleased to see him
I close the door, take Isabel into an embrace and kiss her. I have intercourse with her passionately. I then ask her to get dressed so we can inspect the new chapel together.

The Queen's Chambers, Royal Alcázar
Early Afternoon, Early February 1431

Juan closes the door firmly and draws Isabel into his arms. She comes willingly, her initial surprise melting into warmth as he kisses her. What follows is natural between husband and wife—passionate on his part, willing and affectionate on hers.

Afterward, as they lie together briefly, Isabel rests her head against his chest, quiet and content. There's a peacefulness to the moment, the winter afternoon light streaming through the windows.

"The chapel," Juan reminds her after a time.

Isabel nods, sitting up and reaching for her discarded clothing with that particular mixture of modesty and practicality. "Yes, of course. I've been eager to see it completed."

She dresses with Juan's help—the complex gowns require assistance—and calls for Doña Beatriz to help with the final adjustments and her veil. The older Portuguese lady enters with knowing discretion, asking no questions, simply helping her mistress become presentable again.

Within a quarter hour, they're both properly dressed. Isabel links her arm through Juan's as they leave her chambers, her cheeks still slightly flushed but her bearing composed.

The Portuguese Chapel, Royal Alcázar
Mid-Afternoon

The chapel is in the eastern wing of the Alcázar, a modest space that's been thoroughly transformed over the past month. As Juan and Isabel enter, the change is immediately apparent.

The previous Castilian decorations have been replaced with distinctly Portuguese elements. The altar cloth bears Portuguese heraldry—the five blue shields on white. Portuguese saints have been added to the niches: Saint Anthony of Lisbon (patron of Portugal), Saint Isabel of Portugal (the Queen's namesake), and others. The windows have been fitted with new glass in blue and white, casting colored light across the stone floor.

Most significantly, a small shrine has been established on the right side—clearly for private devotion. It contains a beautifully carved wooden statue of the Virgin Mary in Portuguese style, surrounded by candles and a kneeling bench covered in blue velvet.

Early March 1431 - Six Days

Day One: Departure from Toledo (March 2nd)

The column departs Toledo in the early morning light—a sight that draws crowds to watch. King Juan II in his white Milan plate armor astride a warhorse, the crusader banner unfurled and carried by a dedicated bearer, fifty crusaders in white surcoats as escort, Isabel in a covered wagon with her Portuguese ladies, followed by supply carts, servants, and guards. The weather is unexpectedly perfect for early March. The winter rains have passed but spring heat hasn't yet arrived. Clear skies, mild temperatures, roads firm from several days without rain. The kind of traveling weather that seems like a gift.

Isabel starts the journey nervous, clutching the side of her wagon as it lurches into motion. But as the hours pass and Toledo falls behind, something shifts in her demeanor. She opens the wagon curtains, letting in light and air. The Portuguese ladies chatter around her, pointing out landmarks, making the journey feel less like an ordeal and more like an adventure.

Day Two: Through La Mancha (March 3rd)

The second day takes them deeper into La Mancha—the vast, flat heartland of Castile. The landscape is austere but has a stark beauty: endless plains, distant windmills, small villages of white-washed houses. The sky seems impossibly large.

Isabel rides horseback again for most of the day. Something about the open country affects her—perhaps the sense of space, of possibility. She's more animated than Juan has ever seen her at court. The Portuguese ladies notice it too, exchanging pleased glances.

The third day brings the first gentle hills as they approach the Sierra Morena foothills. The terrain becomes more varied—olive groves, oak forests, streams cutting through valleys. The weather continues perfect.

The fourth day takes them into proper mountain passes. The road becomes steeper, more winding. Progress slows but the scenery is spectacular—peaks rising around them, eagles circling overhead, spring flowers beginning to bloom in sheltered valleys.

Isabel continues to surprise everyone with her resilience. No complaints about the harder terrain, no requests to slow down. If anything, she seems energized by the challenge. I don't know. More capable than I thought. Like I'm discovering I can do things I didn't know I could do."

Day Five: The Courier (March 6th)

It's during the afternoon rest stop that a courier catches up with them—a rider who's been pursuing the column since Toledo. He carries letters, including one sealed with Portuguese royal marks addressed to Queen Isabel.

From that moment of shared vulnerability, real love began. Not the distant, formal partnership of duty, but genuine affection, trust, desire. Now, twenty years later, your father is not just my king and husband—he is my dearest friend, the person I trust most in the world.

Trust him with your fears. Trust him with your inadequacies. Trust him with the parts of yourself you usually hide. Give yourselves time—not just months, but years—to grow into love. It will not happen overnight, but I truly believe it can happen.

I see in your letters that you already care for him more than you perhaps realize. You worry when he trains too hard. You think about how to please him. You notice small details about his moods. These are the first tender shoots of love beginning to grow.

Be patient with yourself. Be patient with him. Be brave enough to be vulnerable. And know that your father and I pray for you every day, that your marriage might become as blessed as ours has been.

With all my love,
Your mother"

"She's right," Isabel whispers. "I've been so afraid of doing everything wrong, of disappointing you, that I've only shown you the dutiful princess. The girl who does everything correctly. But that's not... that's not all of me."
